abstractText: Translocation of messenger RNA (mRNA) and transfer RNA (tRNA) substrates through the ribosome during protein synthesis, an exemplar of directional molecular movement in biology, entails a complex interplay of conformational, compositional, and chemical changes. The molecular determinants of early translocation steps have been investigated rigorously. However, the elements enabling the ribosome to complete translocation and reset for subsequent protein synthesis reactions remain poorly understood. Here, we have combined molecular simulations with single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer imaging to gain insights into the rate-limiting events of the translocation mechanism. We find that diffusive motions of the ribosomal small subunit head domain to hyper-swivelled positions, governed by universally conserved rRNA, can maneuver the mRNA and tRNAs to their fully translocated positions. Subsequent engagement of peptidyl-tRNA and disengagement of deacyl-tRNA from mRNA, within their respective small subunit binding sites, facilitate the ribosome resetting mechanism after translocation has occurred to enable protein synthesis to resume. sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Protein synthesis is facilitated by the ribosome: a massive, two-subunit ribonucleoprotein complex ubiquitous in all domains of life. Protein production in the cell requires repetitive elongation cycles in which deacylated transfer RNA (deacyl-tRNA) and peptidyl-tRNA cargo, paired with messenger RNA (mRNA) (the tRNA2-mRNA module), move directionally through the aminoacyl (A), peptidyl (P) and exit (E) binding sites of the ribosome (70S in prokaryotes; 80S in eukaryotes). These tRNA binding sites, which are comprised of both ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and ribosomal proteins, form by the union of the small (SSU) and large (LSU) ribosomal subunits (30S and 50S in prokaryotes; 40S and 60S in eukaryotes). Deacyl- and peptidyl-tRNA reside within the P and A sites of the pre-translocation ribosome complex (PRE) and move to E and P sites,

respectively, in the post-translocation ribosome complex (POST). Accurate and rapid movement of the tRNA2mRNA module is critical to both translation fidelity and cell growth, a fact underscored by the multitude of smallmolecule antibiotics that target the translocation process (1,2).
The translocation mechanism, while an intrinsic property of the PRE complex, is dramatically accelerated (∼1,000– 50,000-fold) by the essential G protein, elongation factor G (EF-G) in bacteria (eEF2 in eukaryotes) (3,4). EF-G hydrolyses GTP during translocation and coordinates the large-scale intramolecular rearrangements that enable the precise movement of the tRNA2-mRNA module by a single mRNA codon. In so doing, EF-G helps maintain the correct reading frame between the genome and proteome (4–34).
Translocation intermediates, as well as fully translocated (POST) ribosome complexes, have been structurally resolved over a range of spatial resolutions using a variety of biochemical systems and techniques (5–14). Nomenclature used to describe EF-G-bound ribosome conformations and intermediates of translocation is correspondingly complex (i.e. PRE 1–5, TIPRE, TIPOST, chimeric (CHI) states, INT 1–3 etc.) (5,8,11,12,15,34–40). Such translocation intermediates––defined here as the states adopted after peptide bond formation and up to the fully translocated (POST) ribosome complexes after EF-G release – can be interpreted as conformations adopted on a translocation energy landscape (Figure 1A) (32). The principal degrees of freedom on this rugged, EF-G-directed landscape include changes in the positioning of all three SSU domains (body, head, and platform) with respect to the LSU. These include SSU head domain swivel (SSU head domain movement in the direction of translocation relative to the SSU body domain) and a variety of altered tRNA positions both with respect to each other, as well as the SSU and LSU domains. Such states include the PRE-classical (PRE-C) conformation (in which the SSU is unrotated (non-rotated) with respect to the LSU), deacyl-/PRE-hybrid 1 (PRE-H1)/PREhybrid 2 (PRE-H2)/(PRE1-5) basin, the INT1/TIPRE basin, the INT2/chimeric (CHI1-3)/TIPOST basin, INT3, and the post translocation (CHI4/CHI5/POST) basin. For clarity, we will refer to these as PRE, INT1, INT2, INT3 and POST, based on the configuration of the SSU arrangement.
A structurally and kinetically integrated translocation framework, derived from single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer (smFRET) and high-resolution (∼2.7 Å) cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) investigations, postulates that INT1 represents a rapidly-transited EF-G bound ribosome conformation defined by complete and partial translocation of deacyl- and peptidyl-tRNA with respect to the LSU, respectively, a ‘fully’ clockwise rotated (∼10◦) SSU relative to the LSU, and a partially swivelled SSU head domain (6,8,15). The more slowly transited INT2 conformational basin exhibits partially reversed SSU body rotation, a translocation-promoting swivel of the SSU head domain relative to the SSU body, and fully translocated positions of both tRNAs with respect to the LSU (8,15). The anticodon stem loop domains (ASLs)
of deacyl- and peptidyl-tRNA within the tRNA2-mRNA module make their largest movement relative to the SSU body in the INT1 to INT2 transition, achieving positions that are translocated by approximately two-thirds of a single mRNA codon. Rate-limiting passage from the INT2 basin to POST occurs via the highly transient INT3 intermediate that brings the tRNA ASLs to their final translocated positions with respect to the SSU body (15,41). The completion of translocation returns the SSU body and head domains to their fully unrotated and unswivelled positions, respectively. This transition includes events that promote EF-G(GDP) dissociation from the POST complex. These final translocation steps reset the ribosome to continue subsequent translation elongation reactions.
An important feature of this structural and kinetic framework of translocation is that the rate-limiting transition from INT2 to POST entails reversible INT3 sampling from the relatively stable INT2 basin within the EF-G(GDP) bound ribosome complex (15). INT2 to INT3 transitions are hypothesized to be diffusive, spontaneous events involving ‘exaggerated’ or ‘hyper’ swivel motions of the SSU head domain that facilitate positioning of the peptidyltRNA and mRNA pair into the SSU P site (8,15). By contrast, others have hypothesized that tilting motions of the SSU head away from the SSU body domain resolve the transitions from INT2 to the POST state along an axis perpendicular to head swivel (15,42). The nature of these late translocation events remains to be elucidated. In the present investigations, we utilize molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to explore whether one or both conformational processes are required for the penultimate step of translocation.
MD simulations have previously been successful at describing ribosome motions and associated free energies (43– 45). Coupling insights from MD and smFRET has proven particularly powerful for delineating atomistic descriptions of transition paths between metastable states and the physical underpinnings of rate-limiting transition states (46– 52). Using all non-hydrogen atom MD simulations, we show here that the experimentally observed INT2-to-INT3 and INT3-to-POST transitions can be parsimoniously explained by hyper-swivel motions of the SSU head domain within the EF-G-bound ribosome complex. Hyper-swivel of the SSU head domain extends the predominant axis of motion, evidenced in early translocation steps. Hyperswivel is made sterically feasible by narrowly constrained corridors composed of both rRNA and ribosomal proteins that are highly conserved. The scissor-like intramolecular conformational change between the SSU head and body domains enables deacyl-tRNA to disengage mRNA in the E site and ensures proper positioning and engagement of peptidyl-tRNA in the P site. In addition to its likely underpinning of the rate-limiting translocation step observed by smFRET (15), these findings suggest that diffusive SSU head domain motions play a key role in the proposed Brownian ratchet mechanism. More specifically, our findings suggest that diffusive SSU head domain motions enable INT3 passage within the EF-G(GDP) bound ribosome complex to facilitate ribosome resetting to the POST state and continued protein synthesis.

sections.heading: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sections.text:
Preparation of INT1, INT2, POST and INT3 models and different head swivel structures
For the INT2 and POST states, Escherichia coli ribosome models consisting of all heavy (non-hydrogen) atoms were constructed from PDB-ID: 4V7B (12) (INT2) and PDB-ID: 4V5F (7) (POST). Initial analysis for the INT2 state was performed with a T. thermophilus model PDB-ID: 4V5N (5)
and then was refined and verified with a model from E. coli PDB-ID: 4V7B (12). The INT1 state was modeled from the TIPRE cryo-EM approximation of the intermediate conformation from the PBD-ID: 4V5M (5). The A/P tRNA was modeled into the INT1-like state using the tRNA PDB-ID: 4V7B as a starting point (12). To make a complete INT1like ribosome structure, the A/P configuration of the aatRNA was modeled by enforcing codon-anticodon interactions in the A site of the SSU and canonical interac-

Nucleotide and protein sequences were mutated in visual molecular dynamics (VMD) to match E. coli (53) or homology modeled as previously described (54,55). All corresponding models contained the E. coli sequence for rRNA and proteins without nucleotide modifications. The deacyl-tRNA in all models was unmodified tRNAMet and the tRNA in the position of the peptidyl-tRNA was unmodified tRNAPhe. The encoding mRNA maintained the sequence 5′-GGUAAAAAUGUUUAAAAAA-3′. Clashes between the LSU and EF-G were resolved with simulated annealing performed in NAMD 2.12 by incrementally increasing the temperature of the region local to the clashes by 10 K for 40 steps until 1000 K was achieved (56). The structure was then relaxed through the steepest descent energy minimizations using NAMD 2.12 with CHARMM C36 force fields for 500 steps (56,57).
INT3 structures were modeled by restraining the coordinates of the SSU body and rotating the head domain beyond the INT2 position, along the same rotational axis as the INT1-to-INT2 head swivel rotation. Under these conditions, RMSD restraints were imposed on the SSU body, LSU, L1, tRNA, EF-G and mRNA, treating each as rigid bodies (for the initial starting structure for fully flexible bodies in molecular dynamics simulations) to produce the hyper-swivelled state (Supplementary Table S1). Each RMSD restraint was applied to the P and C5′ atoms for RNA and C atoms for proteins. Distance restraints for H-bonds were applied considering stereochemistry (donoracceptor atoms and hydrogen atoms) and a 3.5 Å cutoff distance, where H-bond angles were not restricted. Restraint weights were assigned to reflect the relative rigidity of the molecule. For example, intramolecular interactions within ribosomal subunits are more stable than the intramolecular interactions within tRNA. Iterative refinement of the restraints was performed to achieve the hyper-swivelled state. To define the axis of rotation between the domains, we considered only residues of the core of the body and head to rotate the head of the SSU relative to the body, described previously (42) (Supplementary Table S2). To obtain the hyper-swivel of the INT3 model, we used NAMD 2.12(56) with CHARMM C36 force fields (57) to perform minimization (1200 steps), equilibration (40 000 steps), and targeted MD simulations (100 000 steps) and using restraints with PLUMED2(58), listed in Supplementary Table S1. In these simulations a timestep and cut-off distances of 2 fs and 12.0 Å, respectively, were used. Temperature was maintained at 300 K and Generalized Born Implicit Solvent model (GBIS) (59) was used. These parameters were implemented in targeted MD simulations, maintaining restraints outlined in Supplementary Table S1 to produce MD simulations consistent with smFRET studies. Using targeted MD simulations and restraints, we created five models with different head swivel angles ranging from 16 to 24◦ differing by 2◦.
Preparation of FRET dyes for simulations
To simulate the smFRET experiment as described in Wasserman et al. (15), we modeled 5 FRET dyes (Cy3, Cy5 and LD550, LD650, LD750) using Avogadro 1.2.0 (60). Parameters for each dye were constructed correspond-
ing to the SMOG-v2 protocol (61), the peptide backbone, fluorophore linker and fluorophore were treated as single molecules. These treatments of fluorophores were previously used to recapitulate smFRET data (48) and provide a highly dynamic molecule. Cy3 and Cy5 were attached to the tRNAs at s4U8 by maleimide-thiol chemistry, or acp3U47 by N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) ester crosslinker. LD550, LD650 and LD750 were anchored to S13(N-Sfp), L1(T202C) or L5(N-Acp), EF-G (C-Sfp), respectively as described in Wasserman et al. (15).

Measuring intersubunit rotation and intrasubunit head-swivel
Angles for the intersubunit rotation and intrasubunit headswivel were measured using a previously described approach (42). Residues were selected to ensure that the rigid body angles between domains or subunits were measured instead of fluctuations of flexible regions of the ribosome (Supplementary Table S2). Residues G237, C811 and G1488 were used to define a plane of the SSU to which the angles of intersubunit rotation could be measured by comparing the vector of this plane to a reference structure (INT1). Similarly, residues A977, U1298 and A1374 of the SSU head were used to define a plane to measure the head swivel and head tilt angles. The angles were calculated using VMD v1.9.3 as previously described (42,53). All distance measurements for the MD simulations, or from the PDB data set, were performed using the GROMACS v2018.1 g dist package (64). The reference axis used to compare all models to was derived between INT1 and INT2 states, enabling differentiation between head tilt and swivel.
Comparison between available PDB structures
Both X-ray crystallography and cryo-EM structures of ribosomes were retrieved from the protein databank (rcsb.org). Distances and angles measures to compared PDB structures were all performed in VMD using in house developed scripts (53).

sections.heading: RESULTS
sections.text:
Hyper-swivel motions involved in the structural transitions for translocation resetting
Pre-steady state smFRET measurements of EF-G catalysed translocation have led to the hypotheses (i) that movement of peptidyl-tRNA into the P site is the rate-limiting feature
of the translocation mechanism and (ii) that barrier crossing to the fully translocated POST state likely requires an exaggerated, hyper-swivel motion of the SSU head domain (15). The fluorophores employed for these investigations were positioned on the N-termini of ribosomal proteins uS13 and uL5 via short peptide tags (Figure 1B–D) (15). As this labelling strategy adds uncertainties to the precise FRETdistance relationship, it was previously not possible to unambiguously discern whether the observed change in FRET was due to hyper-swivel or a tilting motion (42) of the SSU head domain away from the LSU (Supplementary Figure S1).
Hyper-swivel of the SSU head domain was, however, previously proposed as the most parsimonious model to explain the INT3 intermediate observed by smFRET, as such motion would represent a continuation of the headswivel trajectory in the INT1-to-INT2 transition accompanying movement of the tRNA2–mRNA module during early translocation. In this view, return of the head domain to the unswivelled position would only require disengagement from the deacyl-tRNA and reverse swivel motions rather than an orthogonal tilting of the head away from its prior trajectory of motion and the LSU. While relatively small extents of SSU head domain tilting (<4◦) away from the LSU have been documented in prokaryotic systems (Supplementary Figure S2), SSU head domain tilt requires a switch in the dominant axis of motion and as shown below, would require a head tilt motion (∼12◦). SSU head domain tilt would also be insufficient to contribute to required directional movements of the tRNA2–mRNA module without additional action from other features of the EFG bound ribosome complex.
We considered published, experimentally determined structures with similar head-swivel, intersubunit rotations, and mRNA positioning as PRE-like, INT1-like, INT2-like or POST-like for this analysis (Supplementary Table S3 and Methods). To examine the feasibility of the hyperswivel model, we extended the swivel-like motions inferred from the INT1-like and INT2-like structural models. Single-molecule FRET investigations suggest that fluctuations between the INT2 and INT3 states, measured by changes in the distance between ribosomal proteins uL5 and uS13, represent the rate-limiting barrier to completion of translocation (15,41). that hyper-swivel motions of the SSU head domain, coupled to reverse rotation of the SSU body, are necessary and sufficient to position the tRNA2–mRNA module in its fully translocated position relative to the SSU body domain (Figure 8). Continuation along the reaction coordinates of SSU head domain swivel and reverse body rotation established during early steps in the translocation mechanism are sufficient to enable this movement (Supplementary Figure S10) (15). The present findings further suggest that ribosome resetting to an unrotated, unswivelled conformation in the POST state requires only modest adjustments in the position of deacyl-tRNA within the E site and recognition of peptidyl-tRNA in the P site. These considerations alleviate the need for energetically unfavorable and orthogonal SSU head domain motion, such as its tilting away from the LSU (42), during ribosome resetting. In the titling model, rescaling of the contacts between the head and body domains of the SSU may have artificially weakened the interactions between these domains to promote the tilting mechanism. In contrast, the hyper-swivel model positions the tRNAs to their final translocated position in a congruent motion that allows for reverse head swiveling and resetting of translocation. Such findings are consistent with smFRET data evidencing that the rate-limiting features of the translocation mechanism persist even after deacyl-tRNA has dissociated from the E site (15,41).
A critical insight from our findings is that diffusive SSU head domain motions to hyper-swiveled positions con-
tribute to the Brownian ratchet mechanism of translocation. In this view, thermally driven hyper-swivel head domain positions represent barrier crossing attempts at forward progression of tRNA2-mRNA module and peptidyltRNA engagement at the SSU P site. The E and AP loops serve as structural guides in this context to ensure fidelity during the final stages of tRNA2–mRNA module movement. The E loop recognizes complete translocation of the tRNA2–mRNA module and likely provides a physical barrier to motion that facilitates deacyl-tRNA disengagement from mRNA and its ultimate dissociation. The AP loop restricts ribosome resetting and the return of the SSU head domain to its unswivelled position until proper positioning of the peptidyl-tRNA in the P site after translocation.
Interpreting the ribosome as a Brownian ratchet, the mRNA, which undergoes unidirectional motion through the ribosome, is analogous to the wheel of the ratchet, while the tRNAs act as the ‘teeth’ on the ratchet wheel. A unique feature of the ribosome ratchet system is that the teeth are detachable. That is, during protein synthesis, tRNA molecules––deacylated by peptide bond formation––ultimately detach from the mRNA and dissociate. In addition to the conformational changes in EF-G subsequent to inorganic phosphate release that facilitate the process of peptidyl-tRNA recognition in the P site, appropriate timing of deacyl-tRNA release from the E site of the ribosome after peptide bond formation must also be considered as a source of unidirectionality in translo-

We infer from our findings that pawl contributions arise from a combination of the PE loop and A/P loop, in conjunction with peptidyl-tRNA recognition and deacyl-tRNA dissociation, facilitating a net-forward movement of the tRNA2mRNA module. Here, the interaction between the tRNA and the aforementioned components of the SSU head domain are analogous to the physical interactions between the wheel tooth and the pawl. The hinge region between the SSU head and body (neck) is analogous to the spring connected to the pawl, which may provide a restoring force when mRNA movement is complete. Together with steric ‘stopper’ restrictions (uS2, uS5, B5, B2a/d, h1 and h36), this contributes to the rising shape of the sawtooth in the ratchet wheel. The binding energies associated with peptidyl-tRNA recognition within the SSU P site upon complete translocation of mRNA, and the unidirectionality provided by deacyl-tRNA dissociation, represent the barrier imposed by the opposite side of the sawtooth that prevents backwards motion. The hyper-swivel model of translocation proposed provides a framework that is consistent with the ribosome as a Brownian ratchet (5,11,20,114,115).
The hyper-swivel model is also consistent with evidence of miscoding-induced stalling of peptidyl-tRNA translocation, which persists long after deacyl-tRNA dissociation and characterized by repetitive INT2-to-INT3 transitions to achieve complete translocation (41). In our MD simulations of cognate codon-anticodon interactions, the AP loop can narrowly traverse past peptidyl-tRNA during re-
verse head-swivel. We therefore infer that slight perturbations to the position of the peptidyl-tRNA cargo, such as those expected to arise from miscoding (116), may lead to higher probability of steric hinderance via clashes between the peptidyl-tRNA and the AP loop. The need for reverse head-swivel to traverse both tRNAs may help explain why tRNA identity can influence elongation rates (117).
Frameshifting, a core feature of the translational regulation of viruses such as HIV-1 and SARS-CoV-2, occurs when the ribosome encounters slippery mRNA sequences (a sequence where a tRNA can decode the –1, 0 or + 1 reading frame) (118,119). Bacterial ribosomes deficient in uL31, which provides a physical link between the LSU central protuberance and head of the SSU, have been found to undergo more frameshifting (120,121). We speculate that the loss of uL31 would likely increase the extent and range of diffusive SSU head domain motions that accompany late-translocation steps, potentially including the INT2-toINT3 transitions preceding POST state formation (Supplementary Figure S11). This would provide an important connection between head swivel regulation and frameshifting. Specific mutations in EF-G have also been found to promote frameshifting (122,123), likely by altering the nature and rate of reversible conformational changes within the protein and the ribosome that govern transitions between the INT2 and INT3 states. The observation that ribosomal protein uS7 influences both +1 and –1 frameshifting (124) suggests that its interactions with nucleotides upstream of the E-site mRNA codon further contribute to the SSU head domain hyper-swivel reaction coordinate.
